Celest Documentation

Celest is a satellite mission planning project designed for the University of Toronto Aerospace Team which is employing the program for their hyperspectral imaging CubSat mission. The library aims to provide the necessary tools to plan satellite-ground interactions such as ground target tracking, and calculating imaging and ground transmission opportunities.

Being subjected to a design team workflow, Celest is consistently under development for improvements in effciency, functionality, and fidelity. It is then expected that the library will be updated regularly and in a timely manner.

What can the program do?

The program only requires an imput data set for a satellite that contains the positions in either a gcrs, itrs, or geographical coordinates and the assosciated Julian times. The program will then be used to calculate various position and time representations, satellite to ground encounters, and transformations necessary for ground location tracking.

What can be expected of the project?

In the near future, a high order c-implemented orbit propagator will be incorporated into the library to allow a complete mission planning workflow from inputing orbital parameters to calculating satellite-to-ground encounter opportunities.

We also intend to incorporate a window scheduling system that will be used to develope an optimal satellite itinerary for satellite missions planning.

Other featurs that are being considered include a terminal interface, higher fidelity conversion calculations, window/data visuals, data loaders, and more robust ground tracking by incorporating forward motion compensation.
